[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: AnnounceElectionFor()] [Token Theft] Can an attacker call AnnounceElectionFor with input.Admin set to their own address to gain admin control over a candidate they don't own, at lines 127-131? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: AnnounceElectionFor()] [Double Spending] Can LockCandidateNativeToken at line 132 be called twice in same transaction if AnnounceElection(pubkeyBytes) at line 126 calls it again, causing double token lock? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: AnnounceElectionFor()] [DoS] Can an attacker register candidates on behalf of others without permission, locking their own tokens and filling DataCentersRankingList to prevent legitimate candidates? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: AnnounceElectionFor()] [State Corruption] If the same pubkey is registered via both AnnounceElection and AnnounceElectionFor, can this create duplicate entries in ManagedCandidatePubkeysMap at lines 129-131? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: AnnounceElectionFor()] [Logic Error] Can the sponsor at line 140 be different from the admin at line 127, creating confusion about who should receive unlocked tokens on quit? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: AnnounceElectionFor()] [Input Validation] Does ByteArrayHelper.HexStringToByteArray at line 124 properly validate input.Pubkey format, or can malformed hex cause parsing errors or unexpected behavior? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: AnnounceElection(byte[])] [Authorization Bypass] Can initial miners who quit and then try to re-register bypass the check at line 149-150 if they are no longer in InitialMiners.Value.Value? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: AnnounceElection(byte[])] [State Manipulation] If candidateInformation exists but IsCurrentCandidate is false at line 156, can an attacker re-announce preserving old CandidateInformation state (terms, missed slots) to gain unfair advantages? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: AnnounceElection(byte[])] [Logic Error] Does setting AnnouncementTransactionId to Context.OriginTransactionId at line 158 allow transaction replay attacks if the same OriginTransactionId is used maliciously? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: AnnounceElection(byte[])] [State Inconsistency] If IsPubkeyBanned check at line 165 only applies to new candidates, can previously banned candidates who quit re-announce by going through the candidateInformation != null path? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: AnnounceElection(byte[])] [State Corruption] Can adding the same pubkeyByteString to State.Candidates.Value.Value at line 174 create duplicates if called multiple times due to race conditions? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: AnnounceElection(byte[])] [DoS] Can an attacker continuously add candidates to State.Candidates.Value.Value list at line 174 to bloat storage and increase gas costs for all candidate-related operations? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: LockCandidateNativeToken()] [Authorization] Is the TransferFrom at line 187 vulnerable if Context.Sender hasn't approved the election contract, causing silent failures or allowing locks without actual token transfer?
